{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3541182,"name":"S.Dukes","username":"CBBearBots","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/cbbearbots/{size}/256425_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-26T15:08:05.321Z","cooked":"

Hello all. Our team has been reading Chief Delphi for a few years now but this is our first post. We are one week out from our first competition (3 weeks from second) and I was looking into upgrading our autonomous programming. We’ve been competing since Stronghold but our programming has always been straightforward (read simple) as we are a very small team and I have had very limited student involvement. With my best ever programmer graduating last year, our new and I programmer have been slogging through this year.
What I am hoping for is a bare bones addition to our robot to use PathPlanner perhaps this year but definitely moving forward. We are having issues finding clear and simple methods for integrating PathPlanner with mecanum. We program in Java. Any and all help would be greatly appreciated.

Is your Mecanum code based on this base example code?

github.com

allwpilib/wpilibjExamples/src/main/java/edu/wpi/first/wpilibj/examples/mecanumco...

Official Repository of WPILibJ and WPILibC. Contribute to wpilibsuite/allwpilib development by creating an account on GitHub.

If it is implementing the auto builder into your drivetrain subsystem should be very similar if not the same as Swerve

https://pathplanner.dev/pplib-build-an-auto.html#configure-autobuilder

I recommend putting the code onto GitHub or something similar to be
able to share a link to it here.

FIRST Robotics Competition Documentation

Git Version Control Introduction

Git is a Distributed Version Control System (VCS) created by Linus Torvalds, also known for creating and maintaining the Linux kernel. Version Control is a system for tracking changes of code for d...

It’s easy to make a repository for your code.
Since you are new to this I would suggest using the Github desktop app
Clone the repository to your computer, which will just create an empty folder to start out with.

Copy your whole code project into that folder
Then the github desktop app will show all the files as changes that need to be committed to the repository.

GitHub Docs

Creating your first repository using GitHub Desktop - GitHub Docs

You can use GitHub Desktop to create and manage a Git repository without using the command line.
